The mechanism of water deactivation and H2 regeneration on Pd/θ-Al2O3 for lean oxidation of propane. Pd/Al2O3 is widely used to eliminate hydrocarbon volatile organic compounds (VOCs) via catalytic oxidation under lean conditions. However, a long-standing issue with this catalytic system is the rapid deactivation of the catalyst due to H2O poisoning. In this study, we employed a variety of regeneration methods to treat deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3, and then conducted detailed characterizations using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) to explore the underlying mechanisms of catalyst deactivation and regeneration. Our findings indicate that only surface hydroxyls that form on PdO or at the PdO-Al2O3 boundary exhibit poisoning effects. Among the regeneration methods tested, a reduction treatment with H2, followed by in situ or ex situ reoxidation, proved to be the most effective in eliminating these poisoning surface hydroxyls and restoring the highly active form of PdO. In contrast, treatment in O2 at elevated temperatures, although highly efficient in eliminating surface hydroxyls, does not restore the highly active PdO form. This is likely due to adverse high-temperature morphological transformation of PdO that lowers the reactant activation capacity. Currently, the abatement of hydrocarbons (HCs) VOCs primarily utilizes two methods: one is recovery such as adsorption or membrane separation, and the other is elimination such as flaring or catalytic complete oxidation [4]. Catalytic complete oxidation is considered by many as the preferred approach as it can directly convert HCs into CO2 and H2O [5–7] at moderate operating temperatures [8]. However, light hydrocarbons (HCs) released from automobiles, petrochemical processes, natural gas processing plants, etc., are typically less reactive than VOCs that contain other heteroatoms (e.g., O and N) [9,10], finding suitable catalysts for efficient C–H bond activation is a challenging task; particularly, saturated short-chain HCs such as methane, ethane and propane are the most difficult ones to eliminate [4,9–11]. Noble metals such as Pd and Pt are among the best-performing catalysts with high activity at low temperatures, high selectivity toward the target products CO2 and H2O, and good resistance to poisons [12–16]. Particularly, alumina-supported palladium (Pd/Al2O3) is the most extensively used industrial catalyst for the complete oxidation of saturated short-chain HCs; however, Pd/Al2O3 faces severe H2O inhibition and H2O-induced rapid deactivation during applications [17–27]. This problem is daunting since typical HCs/VOCs gas feeds contain large amounts of H2O; for example, exhaust of lean-burn natural gas vehicles (NGV) contains ∼15 % of water vapor [28], and certain chemical plant exhausts may have even higher H2O contents. Understanding the mechanisms behind water inhibition/poisoning is critical for designing new catalysts with improved water tolerance. For Pd catalysts, it is generally agreed that PdO is the catalytically active phase under lean (i.e., oxygen-rich) and relatively low temperature conditions. This notion is supported by the fact that PdO is the thermodynamically stable phase under typical reaction temperatures; only above ∼800 °C can the phase transition from PdO to metallic Pd occur [29]. Many researchers hold the opinion that water-induced deactivation is due to the accumulation of surface hydroxyls, or surface –OH/H2O complexes. For example, Ciuparu et al. [30], through in situ FTIR investigations, proposed that the accumulated surface hydroxyls are associated with the PdO catalytically active phase [21,30]. Depending on the level of hydroxylation, Pd(OH)2 may or may not form. It has been heavily debated whether the formation of Pd(OH)2 is the main reason for PdO deactivation. Barrett et al. [31] utilized X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) measurements to confirm the formation of Pd(OH)2 on Pd/Al2O3 catalysts treated with H2O. However, it has also been pointed out that Pd(OH)2 should not be stable at typical reaction temperatures and hydroxyl accumulation should be limited to PdO surfaces [32]. Indeed, Li et al. [33] demonstrated, via ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), that the presence of the surface Pd-OH (rather than Pd(OH)2) on the surface of a palladium foil during wet methane oxidation. Based on Pd K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements under both wet and dry oxidation conditions, Carlsson et al. [34] also pointed out that the formation of a true Pd(OH)2 phase is not practically possible. Still, some researchers hold the opinion that PdO deactivation is not necessarily associated with surface hydroxyls. For instance, Mortensen et al. [35] proposed that the irreversible deactivation of PdO during methane oxidation reaction is not a surface phenomenon but a morphologic change of the PdO nanoparticles. Chen et al. [36] suggested that the irreversible deactivation of PdO during methane oxidation is caused by the gradual transformation of coordinatively unsaturated Pd sites to fully oxygen-coordinated Pd, which leads to the loss of CH4 activation capacity. It is important to note that the accumulation of surface –OH or –OH/H2O is not limited to the PdO active phase. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR) is commonly used to study water-induced catalyst deactivation; however, it cannot distinguish hydroxyl groups associated with Pd(OH)2, PdO, or the oxide supports. Therefore, for Pd/Al2O3 or other supported Pd catalysts, characterization techniques in addition to FTIR are often required to gain detailed understanding about how water influences the Pd active phase, the oxide supports, and the Pd-support interactions. Coupling FTIR and isotope labelling, Ciuparu discovered that accumulation of hydroxyls obstructs oxygen exchange between PdO and the support [37]. Schwartz et al. [38] reported that below 450 °C, the accumulation of –OH/H2O on Al2O3 and MgO supports caused the decreased CH4 oxidation activity over supported Pd materials. Velin et al. [39] proposed that hydroxylation of active sites at the rim of the PdO particles close to the alumina support seems to be of particular importance for the activity, explaining the main inhibitory effect of water on methane oxidation at low temperatures. Based on the summary of literature reports above, there is still no consensus on how water poisons supported PdO catalysts for HCs complete oxidation. Another point of ambiguity regarding the effects of H2O on supported Pd catalysts is that H2O exhibits both inhibitory (reversible) and poisoning (irreversible) effects at low reaction temperatures. These effects are not readily distinguishable during reaction tests. In previous reports, researchers used characterization techniques such as in situ FTIR, XAS, XPS, etc. to study the formation and evolution of hydroxyl groups during the reaction to probe the deactivation of supported PdO catalysts. However, it is very challenging to distinguish hydroxyl groups from PdO surfaces, PdO-Al2O3 interface or the oxide supports. At the same time, most of these characterization techniques are only able to be analysed qualitatively or semi-quantitatively, with little data available for quantitative analysis. As a result, determining which of these contributions is more significant to overall catalyst deactivation is even more difficult. The study of regeneration is important for both academic research and practical applications. Firstly, it assists in clarifying the deactivation mechanism, and secondly, it helps to propose strategies for designing new highly stable catalysts. Probing the state of the deactivated and regenerated catalysts, in combination with the monitoring the products during regeneration (e.g·H2O, CO2, SO2, etc.), facilitates the identification of the deactivated species. The quantitative analysis of the deactivated species during regeneration, in conjunction with qualitative characterization, enables the determination of their contributions to overall catalyst deactivation. To our knowledge, few detailed studies have been performed for the regeneration of propane oxidation catalysts deactivated from water poisoning. The present work aims to further elucidate the mechanisms of water poisoning in alumina-supported palladium catalysts for complete oxidation of propane. Specifically, we selected Pd/θ-Al2O3 as our catalyst and focused on oxidation of propane under lean conditions as our target reaction. For the partially deactivated catalyst samples, we applied a variety of regeneration methods to assess their effectiveness. We utilized multiple characterization techniques, including XPS, TEM, and in situ DRIFTS, to investigate the mechanisms of catalyst deactivation and regeneration. Through a series of qualitative and quantitative analyses, our key findings include: (1) only surface hydroxyls that form on PdO or at the PdO-Al2O3 boundary exhibit poisoning effects; (2) reduction by H2, followed by in situ or ex situ reoxidation, is the most effective method for catalyst regeneration; and (3) regeneration with O2 alone at elevated temperatures only partly restores catalytic activity, likely due to adverse morphologic changes of the PdO particles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials The θ-Al2O3 support used in this study was prepared by calcining a commercial γ-Al2O3 (PIDC, China) in air at 1000 °C for 4 h. The Pd(NO3)2 solution containing 18.07 wt% of Pd was provided by SPMC (China). All pure and dilute gases were purchased from VISTA GAS (China), including pure N2 (99.99 %), O2 (99.999 %), Ar (99.999 %), and 10 % H2/N2, 10 % H2/Ar, 2 % CO/He, 2 % C3H8/Ar, 2 % C3H8/N2. All dilute gases were prepared using pure components of 99.99 % or higher. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Pd/θ-Al2O3 catalyst with a 1.0 wt% Pd loading was prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method. For each gram of θ-Al2O3, 1.5 mL of Pd(NO3)2 solution with a concentration of 62.6 mmol/L was used. The resulting sample was dried at 120 °C for 1 h and subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 2 h, both in open air. The freshly prepared catalyst was then aged by passing air containing 20 % H2O through the catalyst bed at 650 °C for 50 h. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The propane oxidation reaction (C3H8 + 5O2 → 3CO2 + 4H2O) was carried out at ambient pressure on a fixed-bed tubular microreactor equipped with an online MKS 2030 FTIR gas analyzer for reactant and product analysis. The catalyst sample was loaded into the central section of a quartz reactor tube with an inner diameter of 11 mm. Temperature control of the tube furnace was achieved using a custom-designed control module with PID controllers. A K-type thermocouple was inserted into the center of the catalyst bed for temperature monitoring. Before reaction tests, the catalyst was pretreated in an air flow (300 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h (or pretreated in an air flow with 15 % H2O of 300 mL/min at 300 °C for 10 h). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was carried out on an DX-2800 diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The scan range was from 5 to 85°, with a step of 0.02°. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurements were conducted on a JEOL JEM-F200 microscope operated at 200 kV accelerating voltage and a point resolution of 0.23 nm. The samples were dispersed in ethanol and then subjected to sonication for 30 min to improve dispersion. This was followed by deposition of the suspension onto copper grids, and natural evaporation of the ethanol solvent. Temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 system equipped with a TCD detector. 30 mg catalyst (60–80 mesh) was used for each test. Prior to TPR, the sample was pretreated in a 5 %O2/N2 flow (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to −80 °C in the same flow. Thereafter, a pure Ar flow (30 mL/min) was introduced to purge the residual O2 until the TCD signal became stabilized. Finally, 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min) flow was introduced, and the sample temperature was ramped from −80 °C to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. H2 consumption was recorded using the TCD detector. CO chemisorption experiments were carried out on the same system as H2-TPR. In this case, ∼50 mg catalyst (60–80 mesh) was used for each test. The test procedure was as follows: (1) heat the sample in a 5 %O2/N2 flow (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 30 min; (2) purge the sample with a pure Ar flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min; (3) reduce the sample with a 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min) flow at 400 °C for 30 min; (4) purge the sample with a pure Ar flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min, and then cool the sample to 40 °C; (5) conduct pulse chemisorption with 2 vol% CO/He while recording the effluent with the TCD detector. To estimate Pd dispersions, a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio between exposed Pd and chemisorbed CO was assumed [40]. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm measurements were conducted on an iPore 620 physisorption analyzer. Prior to measurement, all samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo K-ALPHA apparatus equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Wide scan spectra were measured at a step size of 1.0 eV. Pd 3d region narrow scan spectra were recorded at a step size of 0.1 eV. Binding energies (BE) were calibrated using adventitious carbon C 1s BE at 284.8 eV. Powder catalysts were either pre-oxidized (21 %O2/Ar) or pre-reduced (5 %H2/Ar) at 400 °C for 1 h. For H2O adsorption experiments, the sample was maintained 400 °C. In this case, each spectrum was recorded after exposing the catalyst to a designated gas mixture (Ar as balance gas) flow of 50 mL/min for 30 min. Background spectra were acquired on samples treated with pure Ar flow at designated temperatures. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structure characterizations The θ-Al2O3 used here has a specific surface area of 103 m2/g and average pore volume of 0.71 cm3/g. After loading 1.0 wt% Pd, the air-calcined Pd/θ-Al2O3 catalyst displays a specific surface area of 95 m2/g and average pore volume of 0.73 cm3/g (Table 1 ). The dispersion of Pd in the reduced Pd/θ-Al2O3 sample is 12.1 %, measured with CO pulse chemisorption (Table 1). This suggests that in its oxidized form, the PdO particle sizes should be rather large. However, from the XRD measurement results shown in Fig. S1a, θ-Al2O3 and Pd/θ-Al2O3 display essentially identical diffractograms. The absence of PdO diffractions can be rationalized from the rather low Pd loading. H2-TPR result for the air-calcined Pd/θ-Al2O3 is shown in Fig. S1b, where H2 consumption around 5 °C is attributed to PdO reduction, and H2 release around 77 °C is due to the decomposition of PdH x [40,41]. We also applied TEM and STEM imaging to probe metallic Pd and PdO particles in the reduced and oxidized samples, respectively, and the results show that average PdO particle diameter of the fresh catalyst is approximately 6.1 ± 2.5 nm (Table S1 and Fig. S7a-b), largely consistent with the dispersion measurement results. More detailed imaging results will be presented further below. In short, the material characterization results indicate that our Pd/θ-Al2O3 catalyst is a typical, representative supported Pd catalyst with relatively large particle sizes. In the following, detailed propane oxidation reaction data are presented. 3.2 Catalyst deactivation and regeneration coupled with reaction tests Fig. 1 a presents propane conversion rate as a function of time on stream under a reactant feed of 600 ppm C3H8, 5 % O2, with or without 15 % H2O at a WHSV of ∼3333600 mL g−1 h−1. At a reaction temperature of 400 °C, rather rapid deactivation during reaction was observed even in the absence of H2O in the feed, where propane reaction rate drops from 2.7 to 1.9 m o l C 3 H 8 g P d - 1 h - 1 within 8 h of reaction. Upon the addition of H2O to the feed, reaction rate decreased much more rapidly and the catalyst became almost completely deactivated after 8 h of reaction. Raising the reaction temperature to 450 °C resulted in partial recovery of catalytic activity, followed by severe deactivation again. We also carried out a series of light-off tests with or without 15 % H2O in the feed; the results are presented in Fig. S2. On the basis of T50 (i.e., temperatures at which propane conversions reach 50 %) analysis, it is also obvious that catalyst deactivation is more severe in the presence of H2O in the feed. Note that such rapid catalyst deactivation is typical for Pd/Al2O3 catalysts for complete oxidation of propane, which has been repeatedly reported in the literature [17,20,23,39]. Prior investigations have confirmed that both H2O induced reaction inhibition (e.g., competitive chemisorption between reactants and H2O on PdO) and catalyst deactivation (i.e., poisoning of PdO) occur during hydrocarbon oxidation under lean conditions [18,35,42,43]. Furthermore, H2O induced reaction inhibition is reversible, whereas H2O induced catalyst deactivation is irreversible. Our control experiments shown in Fig. S3 demonstrate that both H2O induced inhibition and poisoning occur for lean propane oxidation on our PdO/θ-Al2O3 catalyst. As shown in Fig. S3, rapid decline in reaction rate upon the addition of H2O to the feed can be considered reversible (inhibition effects); upon removal of H2O from the feed, the propane conversion rate largely recovers. However, the continuous decrease in reaction rate with time, regardless of whether water is generated in situ or added deliberatively, should be considered irreversible (i.e., poisoning effects). Since our focus here is to elucidate catalyst deactivation and regeneration mechanisms, H2O inhibition effects are not specifically addressed in the following. To the heavily deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3 catalyst, we attempted regeneration by flowing various gases (200 mL/min) through the catalyst bed for 30 min, followed by propane oxidation tests under wet conditions at 400 °C to elucidate regeneration efficiency. Following such regeneration attempts (Fig. 1b), it is readily seen that only regeneration procedures ⑤–⑦ result in full recovery of the initial activity. A few points are worth noting for these data. First, it is rather surprising that regeneration with O2 at 600 °C (i.e., procedure ②) does not lead to full regeneration, considering that surface hydroxyls should undergo very extensive, if not complete, condensation to desorb as H2O at such a high temperature. Second, procedures ⑤ and ⑥ exhibit rather similar regeneration efficiency, i.e., the O2 treatment step in ⑥, which re-oxidizes metallic Pd to PdO, appears unnecessary for activity recovery. This suggests that at a reaction temperature of 400 °C, the lean feed can promptly oxidize Pd to the catalytically active phase PdO, rendering the pre-oxidation step unnecessary. Third, procedures ⑤ and ⑦ exhibit rather similar regeneration efficiency. It can be deduced from this result that at 400 °C, H2O only poisons PdO but not metallic Pd. For regeneration procedures ①, ② and ⑥, i.e., O2 treatment at 400 °C, O2 treatment at 600 °C, and H2-O2 treatment at 400 °C, we further quantified the amounts of H2O and CO2 formed during regeneration (Figs. S4–S5), and the results are tabulated in Table 2 . For the regeneration with H2-O2, 287.0 μmol/gcat. of H2O and 2.4 μmol/gcat. of CO2 are generated during the H2 reduction step, and 90.8 μmol/gcat. of H2O and 2.1 μmol/gcat. of CO2 are generated during the subsequent O2 oxidation step. Also, regeneration with O2 at 600 °C leads to much larger formation of H2O and CO2 than regeneration with O2 at 400 °C. Control experiments were also carried out using the θ-Al2O3 support. Following propane oxidation at 400 °C for 8 h, the same H2-O2 regeneration at 400 °C revealed negligible H2O and CO2 formation (Fig. S6). The quantification results shown above reveal a few important points regarding deactivation/regeneration of Pd/θ-Al2O3. First, we note that H2O and CO2 yields during regeneration cannot be used to evaluate regeneration efficiency. Particularly, even though much more H2O and CO2 are generated during regeneration in O2 at 600 °C than in H2-O2 at 400 °C, the latter method is much more effective for the restoration of propane oxidation activity (Fig. 1b). Second, for the H2-O2 regeneration method in particular, if we assume that the catalytically active PdO (94.0 μmol/gcat.) completely converts to Pd(OH)2 during reaction, and then fully reduces to metallic Pd during H2 regeneration, the amount of H2O generated from the reduction chemistry (i.e., Pd(OH)2 + H2 → Pd + 2H2O) should be 188.0 μmol/gcat., which is substantially less than the amount (287.0 μmol/gcat.) found during H2 reduction. Since the H2-O2 treatment of the θ-Al2O3 support at 400 °C does not result in measurable H2O formation, this outcome can only be explained by invoking the removal of hydroxyl groups at the PdO-Al2O3 interface, particularly on the Al2O3 domain. Third, irrespective of the regeneration method, much less CO2 is generated during regeneration as compared to H2O, consistent with prior assertions that catalyst deactivation is more strongly associated with the buildup of surface hydroxyls than carbonaceous species [21,30,32,33,37–39,44]. 3.3 The nature of palladium on deactivated and regenerated catalysts The catalyst regeneration results above show that H2 reduction is the most effective regeneration method (Fig. 1b). Next, we used XPS to probe the valence status of Pd and the oxygen species before and after a reduction treatment. Fig. 2 presents the Pd 3d region XPS spectra for selected samples. All samples that have been exposed to oxidizing environments, i.e., air-calcination, used under lean oxidation of propane, re-oxidized with O2 after reduction with H2, or even exposed to the propane oxidation reactant for only 5 min after H2 reduction, display 3d5/2 binding energy (BE) of ∼336.6 eV and 3d3/2 BE of ∼341.9 eV, demonstrating that Pd species in the samples exist as PdO [33,45]. The only exception is the H2-reduced sample that displays 3d5/2 BE of ∼334.8 eV and 3d3/2 BE of ∼340.0 eV, indicative of metallic Pd [33,45]. Importantly, there is no significant difference in the valence state of Pd between the fresh and deactivated catalysts. If bulk Pd(OH)2 is the main Pd species on deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3, then a Pd 3d5/2 BE of ∼337.4 eV is anticipated [46]. Since all of our oxidized samples display a common Pd 3d5/2 BE of ∼336.6 eV (Fig. 2), we conclude that bulk Pd(OH)2 is absent on any of the samples. In addition to Pd 3d, we also examined the O 1s XPS spectra of these samples, as shown in Fig. 3 . For each sample, three O 1s bands are observed. The main band peaks at ∼530.8 eV, typical of lattice oxygen in Al2O3 (denoted OL). The band at ∼532.3 eV is attributed to chemisorbed oxygen (denoted Oads), and the band at ∼533.6 eV is due to surface hydroxyls (–OH) [5]. Their percentages on each sample are readily obtained by peak fitting, and the values are marked adjacent to the corresponding O moieties. Two important points are worth noting for these data: (1) The deactivated sample possesses higher surface OH percentage than any other sample, consistent with prior assertion that the accumulation of surface hydroxyls is a primary catalyst deactivation mechanism. (2) Regeneration with O2 alone does not restore the Oads level to that of the fresh sample (10.1 %), but regeneration with H2 followed by reoxidation effectively restores Oads level (∼8–10 %). In other words, regeneration with O2 alone does not lead to the restoration of O2 activation capacity of the fresh catalyst. This finding aligns well with the propane oxidation results shown in Fig. 1b, i.e., regeneration with O2 alone only partially restores catalytic performance of the fresh catalyst, whereas regeneration with H2 reduction followed by oxidation fully restores catalytic performance. We also applied HR-TEM imaging to probe particle size and faceting of the supported Pd species, as shown in Fig. 4 . On these images, individual Pd particles measuring ∼5–10 nm are observed (more detailed particle size distributions will be shown below based on low-magnification imaging results). Except the freshly H2-reduced sample that displays lattice spacings (marked on the images) that can be indexed to metallic Pd (Fig. 4g, h), all other samples that have been exposed to oxidizing environments display lattice spacings that are readily indexed to PdO. Particularly, by exposing the H2-reduced sample to the lean propane oxidation feed for only 5 min, PdO becomes the only Pd phase that is detected (Fig. 4k, l), confirming prior assertions that PdO is the catalytically active Pd phase under lean HCs oxidation conditions at relatively low temperatures. Interestingly, on fresh Pd/θ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4a, b), and on samples regenerated with H2 + O2 (Fig. 4i, j) or with H2 + lean reaction feed (Fig. 4k, l), PdO(1 0 1) is frequently observed; in contrast, on deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4c, d), and on the sample regenerated with O2 alone (Fig. 4e, f), PdO(200) is frequently observed. Even though we only examined a small number of images and are thus in no position to draw firm conclusions on statistically meaningful faceting of PdO particles, the HR-TEM imaging results are indeed consistent with XPS results shown in Fig. 3, i.e., PdO surfaces on catalytically active samples are capable of accommodating more Oads than PdO surfaces on deactivated or less active samples; one likely explanation is that on catalytically active and inactive samples, PdO particles expose different predominant facets. As noted above, our HR-TEM imaging results do not allow us to gain further details on particle sintering during propane oxidation reaction or the subsequent regenerations. Therefore, we applied low-magnification HAADF-STEM imaging to estimate PdO particle size distribution, and the results are shown in Figs. S7–S8 and Table S1. It is important to note that average PdO particle diameters of the fresh and deactivated catalysts are similar (both are ∼6 nm), indicating that PdO particle sintering is not a key cause of catalyst deactivation. Similarly, no significant particle size variations are observed for catalysts regenerated with methods ② and ⑥, indicating that differences in regeneration efficiency are also unrelated to particle size. Furthermore, ICP results show that all samples contain essentially identical Pd contents, suggesting that catalytic property variations among different catalysts are unrelated to Pd loading (Table S1). 3.4 Correlating catalyst deactivation and regeneration with surface hydroxyls Next, we used in situ DRIFTS to probe regeneration with O2. In this case, partially deactivated catalysts used under dry and wet complete oxidation of propane was exposed to flowing O2 (50 mL/min), and the sample temperature was gradually increased from 400 to 600 °C at 50 °C intervals; at each target temperature, the sample was held for 20 min prior to spectrum acquisition. Fig. 5 presents the evolution of hydroxyls and surface carbonaceous species as a function of regeneration temperature. For the sample used under dry reaction conditions, O2 treatment up to 500 °C removes essentially all surface hydroxyls and surface carbonaceous species, namely, carboxylate species and bicarbonate species [47–50]. For the sample used under wet reaction conditions, due to the presence of more surface hydroxyls, O2 treatment up to 600 °C is required to remove most surface hydroxyls. As shown in Fig. 5a, in the absence of co-fed H2O, a significant amount of surface hydroxyls still accumulates on the catalyst surface during propane oxidation. Based on prior investigations, surface hydroxylation is enabled in this case by H from the propane reactant and the reactively formed H2O product [25,39]. At the reaction temperature of 400 °C, some surface hydroxyls persist even after switching the reactant flow to O2. Combining these results and the propane oxidation results shown in Fig. 1a, it is readily concluded that these stable surface hydroxyls exert poisoning effects, leading to catalyst deactivation in the absence of co-fed H2O. As shown in Table 2, O2 treatment at 600 °C leads to the release of 1.03 mmol/gcat·H2O from deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3. Herein, we provide a brief discussion on theoretical H2O yields from Al2O3 surfaces upon complete dehydration & dehydroxylation. To our knowledge, detailed surface hydroxyl coverages (ΘOH) for θ-Al2O3 have not been reported. According to the orientation relationship between γ-Al2O3 and θ-Al2O3, that is, [110]γ//[010]θ and (001)γ//(100)θ [51], and the fact that θ-Al2O3 preferentially exposes the (010) facet [52,53], we can use the much better reported γ-Al2O3(110) surface characteristics for an estimation. For the γ-Al2O3(110) surface that is treated under a dry environment at 400 °C, ΘOH is around 3.0 OH/nm2 [54–57], whereas for the fully hydroxylated γ-Al2O3(110) surface, ΘOH is around 8.9 OH/nm2 [54,57]. Based on these two values, complete dehydration leads to the formation of 236.7–702.2 μmol/gcat·H2O on a 95 m2/g specific surface area basis. Assuming that all surface hydroxyls create hydrogen bonding with H2O molecules at a 1:1 ratio, complete dehydration & dehydroxylation leads to the generation of 0.71–2.11 mmol/gcat·H2O. Indeed, the formation of 1.03 mmol/gcat. H2O from deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3 (Table 2) is consistent with the fact that before regeneration, the surfaces are covered with both isolated hydroxyls and –OH/H2O complexes (Fig. 5). In the following, we use in situ DRIFTS to examine possible mechanisms on deactivation and regeneration of Pd/θ-Al2O3. To facilitate proper attribution of various surface hydroxyls, we used the θ-Al2O3 support, a pre-reduced Pd/θ-Al2O3 sample (denoted Pd0/θ-Al2O3) and an air-calcined Pd/θ-Al2O3 sample (denoted PdO/θ-Al2O3) as our reference samples. After exposing them to a 3 % H2O/Ar flow at 400 °C for 30 min, the OH vibrational region (νOH) DRIFT spectra were acquired, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 a. The θ-Al2O3 support exhibits poorly resolved weak νOH features in the ∼3750–3000 cm−1 range. Based on prior literature assignments, νOH features with frequencies >3500 cm−1 are generally assigned to isolated hydroxyls, and bands in the 3500–3000 cm−1 range are attributed to hydroxyls with hydrogen bonding to adsorbed H2O [30]. The Pd0/θ-Al2O3 sample displays much stronger and better resolved isolated hydroxyl signals at ∼3722, 3688, 3546 cm−1. Since none of these bands can develop on metallic Pd, and intensities of their counterparts on the θ-Al2O3 support are exceedingly weak, they are most likely located at the Pd-Al2O3 interface (or boundary). On the basis of established convention for hydroxyl categorization on metal oxide surfaces [58,59], the features at ∼3722 and ∼3688 cm−1 are assigned to terminal (denoted OHI) and bridging (denoted OHII) isolated OH species, respectively. The broader absorption band centered at ∼3546 cm−1 (denoted OHIII) is assigned to multiple coordinated hydroxyl species. The band at ∼3487 cm−1, on the other hand, is attributed to surface hydroxyls with H-bond interactions (denoted OHH-bond). Schematics of their structures are included in Fig. 6a. In order to provide a quantitative description of their relative intensities, we calculated the OHII/OI, OHIII/OI and OHH-bond/OI intensity ratios, and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. Compared to Pd0/θ-Al2O3, the PdO/θ-Al2O3 sample exhibits markedly enhanced OHIII/OHI and OHH-bond/OHI ratios. As such, it can be deduced that (1) OHIII and OHH-bond signals are more likely associated with the PdO surface and the PdO-Al2O3 interfacial sites closer to PdO, and (2) OHI and OHII are more likely associated with PdO-Al2O3 interfacial sites closer to Al2O3. Next, we examine the evolution of surface hydroxyls via in situ DRIFTS under propane oxidation and catalyst regeneration conditions at 400 °C. During the experiments, the Pd/θ-Al2O3 sample was first exposed to a N2 gas flow containing 3 %H2O (50 mL/min) for 30 min. After that, O2 was added to the flow. After the exposure of H2O + O2 for 30 min, propane was added to initiate the complete oxidation reaction. After reaction for 30 min, the H2O + O2 + C3H8 feed was switched off, and a H2 flow without H2O was turned on for catalyst regeneration. Upon reduction for 30 min, the H2 flow was turned off, and an O2 flow without H2O was introduced for another 30 min. During these reaction steps, the catalyst was continuously monitored with IR scanning. Fig. 7 a shows the spectra recorded at the end of each gas switching operation (i.e., upon the exposure of the corresponding feed for a full 30 min). During the H2O → H2O + O2 → H2O + O2 + C3H8 sequence, the νOH region spectra are highly similar in terms of signal line shapes; the only notable difference appears to be signal intensity, where the introduction of O2 to H2O causes signal intensity to decrease slightly, and the introduction of C3H8 causes the signal intensity to gain slightly. Because of the unavoidable background drifting effect during such measurements, it is difficult to derive more useful information by comparing these three spectra. Upon the introduction of H2 for 30 min, the overall signal intensity of the νOH region somewhat decreases, but again, this may be partially associated with background drifting. Nevertheless, we also calculated the OHII/OHI, OHIII/OHI and OHH-bond/OHI intensity ratios the same way as that shown in Fig. 6b, and the results are depicted in Fig. 7b. For the sample treated with H2O + O2, the calculated intensity ratios are clearly higher than samples treated with other gases. However, this is mainly due to the fact that upon H2O + O2 treatment, the intensity of the OHI band somehow decreased for reasons that are not clear to us. Other than that, treatment under the H2O → H2O + O2 → H2O + O2 + C3H8 sequence leads to no obvious intensity ratio variations of the νOH bands. Upon reduction with H2, however, OHII/OHI, OHIII/OHI and OHH-bond/OHI intensity ratios decrease remarkably, particularly OHIII/OHI and OHH-bond/OHI. This observation is consistent with our notion above that OHIII and OHH-bond are directly associated with PdO and the PdO-Al2O3 interface. Combining regeneration efficiency (Fig. 1b), H2O quantification during regeneration (Table 2) and in situ DRIFTS (Figs. 5–7), key differences about how surface hydroxyls respond to regeneration with O2 alone and with H2 + O2 can be derived. Particularly, during regeneration with O2, OHIII and OHH-bond are more stable than OHI and OHII; during regeneration with H2 + O2, the exact opposite is found. Therefore, it is firmly concluded that OHIII and OHH-bond are more closely associated with PdO and the PdO-Al2O3 interface, and are thus more detrimental than OHI and OHII. The surface hydroxyls that are directly associated with Pd are readily removed by H2 reduction through the following reaction: Pd-OH + 1/2H2 → Pd0 + H2O. Removal of interfacial hydroxyls that do not link directly to Pd is likely facilitated by hydrogen spillover. From the results and discussions above, we summarize key discoveries that (1) only certain surface hydroxyls play a poisoning role, and reduction with H2 effectively removes such hydroxyls. Consistent with prior reports, our results also suggest that only hydroxyls on PdO and the PdO-Al2O3 interface play the poisoning role. (2) PdO particles free from hydroxyl poisoning, e.g., those regenerated from O2 treatment, are not necessarily highly active for complete oxidation of propane. In this sense, in addition of hydroxylation, morphologic changes of the PdO nanoparticles, or coordination number variation of surface Pd sites, are also plausible for catalyst deactivation as suggested previously [60–65]. Our HR-TEM imaging reveals (Fig. 4) that on the fresh catalyst and on catalysts regenerated with H2 reduction followed by in situ/ex situ oxidation, PdO(101) facet is more frequently observed. In contrast, on the deactivated catalyst and on catalyst regenerated with O2 alone at 600 °C, PdO(200) facet is more frequently observed. Even though we only examined a few samples and such a trend is likely only fortuitus, it is indeed in line with prior assertions that morphologic changes of the PdO may be responsible for catalyst deactivation [32,35,66–69], and further study in detail is required using other in situ characterization techniques. (3) the H2-O2 regeneration process is considered multifunctional, i.e., not only does this method effectively removes the most detrimental surface hydroxyls via H2 reduction, it also restores the catalytically active form of PdO (i.e., favorable surface faceting or surface Pd coordinations) during the subsequent oxidation by O2, either a deliberate O2 feed, or the lean oxidation of propane feed. 4 Conclusions In the present study, through lean oxidation of propane reaction tests, catalyst regeneration tests and a series of characterizations, it is shown that PdO, not metallic Pd, is the catalytically active species under low-temperature lean oxidation conditions. During propane oxidation, hydroxyl groups accumulate on the entire catalyst surface as both isolated hydroxyls and –OH/H2O complexes, but only certain hydroxyls (on PdO particles and PdO-Al2O3 interfaces) are detrimental to catalyst activity through their poisoning effect on the catalyst. This conclusion is confirmed through quantitative analysis of the products during regeneration for the deactivated catalyst, in conjunction with other qualitative characterizations. Regeneration with O2 alone at 600 °C, even though effectively removes essentially all surface hydroxyls, does not lead to full restoration of catalytic activity. Morphologic changes of PdO may be the main reason for such inefficiency. As a comparison, the H2-O2 regeneration process not only removes the most detrimental surface hydroxyls via H2 reduction, but also restores the catalytically active form of PdO (i.e., favourable surface faceting or surface Pd coordinations) during the subsequent oxidation by O2. coredata.dc:description: Pd/Al2O3 is widely used to eliminate hydrocarbon volatile organic compounds (VOCs) via catalytic oxidation under lean conditions. However, a long-standing issue with this catalytic system is the rapid deactivation of the catalyst due to H2O poisoning. In this study, we employed a variety of regeneration methods to treat deactivated Pd/θ-Al2O3, and then conducted detailed characterizations using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) to explore the underlying mechanisms of catalyst deactivation and regeneration. Our findings indicate that only surface hydroxyls that form on PdO or at the PdO-Al2O3 boundary exhibit poisoning effects. Among the regeneration methods tested, a reduction treatment with H2, followed by in situ or ex situ reoxidation, proved to be the most effective in eliminating these poisoning surface hydroxyls and restoring the highly active form of PdO. In contrast, treatment in O2 at elevated temperatures, although highly efficient in eliminating surface hydroxyls, does not restore the highly active PdO form. This is likely due to adverse high-temperature morphological transformation of PdO that lowers the reactant activation capacity.
